content.p: The current version of requires DNSSD to be installed and running. For example, you can use mDNSResponder (Bonjour from Apple).
In order to compile your source code, you will need to have Bonjour, libxml with their C++ headers and libs for bindings.

The Java version of requires a DNSSD implementation to be installed. For example, you will need to install mDNSResponder (Apple Bonjour) together with its Java bindings. See the OSGi tutorial for more details about this installation.

The developement using the non-OSGi version of omiscid just requires to have the following jars in your classpath:
omiscid.jar: the omiscid library
xerces-J_1.4.0.jar, commons-logging.jar, castor-1.0.1-xml.jar, log4j-1.2.8.jar: the base libraries required by Castor XML
jakarta-oro-2.0.8.jar: the apache jakarta oro library required by some Castor XML features
Note that all the dependencies to Castor will probably be replaced when Java 6 will be released and widely available.
You can access the javadoc of the user centered API on this website.

You can use the following resources in order to train yourself using :
the under-development version of the doxygen documentation
a tutorial about using user-friendly interface to build services.

As the C++ and Java APIs are almost identical (modulo the languages specifity), you can probably take the C++ tutorials as a basis. Your favorite IDE will probably allow you to cope with the slight differences between the C++ and Java APIs.
For a detailled description of architecture and design goals, see this paper presented at the IEEE workshop SIPE-2006.
